utterances: Marshall Shepherd is the president of the American Meteorological Society and director of the Atmospheric Sciences Program at the University of Georgia.
I'm Farai Chideya, and this is News & Notes.
He was the star of this year's Super Bowl.
And today, New York Giants star David Tyree is here with us to talk about the catch of his life.
I'm going to pass the ball now to our very own Tony Cox.
Well thank you, Farai.
I'm going to try to catch it and not drop it.
David Tyree's catch will forever be engraved in the minds of football fans.
You might remember that catch back in February during the most-watched Super Bowl in history.

Against tight-end - tight defense late in the fourth quarter, Tyree grabbed Eli Manning's pass, wedging it improbably between his right hand and his helmet - you had to see it - and set up the New York Giants for their upset win over the New England Patriots.
And we'll have - he has a book coming out in September called ""More Than Just a Catch,"" chronicling his path to unlikely Super Bowl heroism.
David's in town for the Espy Awards.
He's nominated for best play, of course, of course.
David, welcome to News & Notes.
(Wide Receiver, New York Giants): Man, I'm truly excited just to be here hanging out with you guys.
You know, David, you have something we don't get to see very often here in Southern California, not since the Raiders left town.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's a Super Bowl ring.
Where is it?
Yeah, we got this nice piece of jewelry up here.
Its - man, I'll tell you what.
You work hard, bless one-twos (ph) all year round just to hopefully wear one of these.
Took Michael Traynor 15, took me five, so I'm doing alright.
That thing's heavy, isn't it?
Yeah, it is pretty heavy, but this kind of weight you don't mind getting right here.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Listen, we talked about the fact that the book ""More Than Just a Catch"" is coming out.
Now that's really quick.
I mean, the Super Bowl was in February.
And here we are in the summer, and the book's coming out in September.
So you must have - tell me - starting working on this before.
Well, you know, I think the book is something that would have, you know, maybe possibly been in the, you know, down the road, you know, say what happened in the Super Bowl never happened.

But when you look at the series of incidents, what God has kind of done in my life, there's no greater, you know, timing, timing is everything, so it's a lot - there's a lot to give in my story, you know.
I've been in some tremendous struggles and it wasn't until I came into this wonderful relationship with Christ, you know, I wanted to, you know, share that with the rest of the world.
Demonstrators in Khartoum are demanding that the military there hand over power to civilians.
Months of protest in Sudan had already led the junta to oust longtime autocrat Omar al-Bashir in April.
But last week, the military rulers turned on the protesters and ordered a violent crackdown.
NPR's Eyder Peralta is in Khartoum.
Thanks so much for being with us.
Thank you, Scott.
Fridays have been the big days of protests there in Khartoum.
I wonder what you saw yesterday.
Yeah.
We went to one of the neighborhoods that was at the heart of this rebellion, and it was a neighborhood where imams would talk politics in the mosques.
And when prayers were done, people would file out and chant antigovernment slogans.
So protests often grew out of Friday prayers.
But yesterday we went to this very significant mosque, and the imam said nothing political.
He explained how Muslims don't necessarily have to visit Mecca for hajj.
And then everyone filed out quietly, and they went home.
So no protests.
So whenever this - is it a revolution?
- is done, it's back to the same old Sudan?
You know, that's hard to tell.
I think - I mean, what's happening right now is a regrouping of sorts.
And people are just thinking through what's happened.
I spent some time with Dr. Mohammed Alawad (ph).
He's an activist.
And he was on the frontlines last week when security forces opened fire on protesters.
He says what he saw was carnage.
And he says that he felt that the young people who went out on the streets, that they had done their jobs.
But he feels betrayed by the military and even by some of his leaders.
I asked him the same question, if he thought this thing was over, if it would be like 2013, when the Sudanese government put down a protest movement.
And let's listen to a bit of what he said.
The killing in the last days was meant to clear - a clear message to people.
But, you know, people by - why - you know, they were killing us from December.
And so I don't think people are afraid of dying now; some people are.
Maybe I am.
Maybe I am - that's the tough realization there, Scott, that more protests will likely mean more deaths.
And I think everyone I've spoken to thinks that there are people willing to die for a better country.
But when I ask them if they are willing to die, they sigh.
You know, I think they're scared.
They're thinking, and they're just trying to come to terms right now.
Is the world paying attention?
Yeah.
I mean, Sudan is important geopolitically.
So, you know, the Gulf countries have been very much involved; Ethiopia is trying to act as mediator.
And this week, you know, we also saw sort of the regular world turn its attention to Sudan when celebrities started tweeting about it.
People all over the world have been turning their profile pictures blue to show solidarity with one of the young protesters who was killed here.
But, you know, right now there's a disconnect in all of that because the government here has shut down the Internet completely; there is no mobile internet here.
And so most Sudanese have no idea what's actually happening.
I understand the military and opposition groups have agreed to have new talks.
Is there any hopefulness about that?
No, I mean, we haven't gotten much progress.
The junta says that they welcome talks, but the opposition says that they don't trust them after the killings.
You know, they say that they will only talk to them through a mediator.
And we haven't really gotten much of an update as to where those talks stand.
NPR's Eyder Peralta in Khartoum.
Thanks so much for being with us.
Thank you, Scott.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
We have a year-end tradition here at Day to Day.
It's called Holiday Leftovers.
These are stories we've aired over the past year that we think are worth revisiting, reheating, if you will.
You might remember a story from last year about a Christmas tree farmer in New Hampshire.
Producer Sean Hurley paid him another visit this past weekend.
(Reading) Dear Santa, it's my first Christmas and my first tree.
Thanks a lot.
Mommy bought you some fudge.
Love, Trey.
This is a family that just had a new baby.
So, maybe they'll have a tradition to come up every year and get one.
That'd be great.
That's Harry Pettit of Campton, New Hampshire.
He was the subject of my very first story for public radio, a story that almost got away from me.
I'd spoken with Harry on the phone, and he'd reluctantly agreed to do an interview.
But when I got out of my car...
(Soundbite of car door closing)
I could tell something was amiss.
(Soundbite of footsteps)
Hi.
How are you doing?
Good.
How're you doing?
Good.
(Soundbite of footsteps)
Did you get my message?
Oh, no, I didn't.
Yeah, I said I wasn't interested.
Oh, I'm sorry.
No, not a problem.
I thought it was someone coming to get a tree.
Ah.
I was just coming out to help him.
Instead, he came out and helped me, by agreeing to go on with the interview about his unique holiday tradition.
